unnormalised: ## Ctrl+Alt+Delete Your Way to IT Sanity (Maybe?)
normalised: ## Control plus Alt plus Delete Your Way to I-T Sanity (Maybe?)

unnormalised: So, you're thinking about a career in Information Technology? Buckle up, buttercup. It's less "Silicon Valley" and more "Silicon Gully," especially if you're doing it in India. We're talking about a profession where your official job title is "Troubleshooter," but your actual role is something closer to "Exorcist of Electronic Demons."
normalised: So, you're thinking about a career in Information Technology? Buckle up, buttercup. It's less "Silicon Valley" and more "Silicon Gully," especially if you're doing it in India. We're talking about a profession where your official job title is "Troubleshooter," but your actual role is something closer to "Exorcist of Electronic Demons."

unnormalised: Let's be real, the IT field is booming in India. From TCS to Infosys, the opportunities are endless. But before you start dreaming of coding in your pajamas, let's address some harsh realities. First, forget 9 to 5. Think more like 9 AM to whenever the server decides to cooperate. Which is approximately never.
normalised: Let's be real, the I-T field is booming in India. From T-C-S to Infosys, the opportunities are endless. But before you start dreaming of coding in your pajamas, let's address some harsh realities. First, forget nine to five. Think more like nine A-M to whenever the server decides to cooperate. Which is approximately never.

unnormalised: I remember my first day at Wipro. They gave me a laptop running Windows XP (yes, XP!) and told me to "fix it." I’m pretty sure that laptop had seen more interns than caffeine breaks. It blue-screened faster than you can say "BSOD." The RAM was only 256 MB! I honestly thought it was a prank.
normalised: I remember my first day at Wipro. They gave me a laptop running Windows X-P (yes, X-P!) and told me to "fix it." I’m pretty sure that laptop had seen more interns than caffeine breaks. It blue-screened faster than you can say "B-S-O-D." The R-A-M was only two hundred and fifty six M-B! I honestly thought it was a prank.

unnormalised: And then there's the acronyms. Oh, the acronyms! You'll need a decoder ring just to understand your colleagues. We're talking HTTP, DNS, VPN, RAM, ROM, SaaS, IaaS, PaaS, and a million others that sound like alien languages. Honestly, I sometimes feel like I’m fluent in Alphabet Soup.
normalised: And then there's the acronyms. Oh, the acronyms! You'll need a decoder ring just to understand your colleagues. We're talking H-T-T-P, D-N-S, V-P-N, R-A-M, R-O-M, S-a-a-S, I-a-a-S, P-a-a-S, and a million others that sound like alien languages. Honestly, I sometimes feel like I’m fluent in Alphabet Soup.

unnormalised: Don't even get me started on the users. Bless their hearts, they're the reason we have jobs. But they also believe that turning the computer off and on again will solve literally any problem. And they will call you at 3 AM because their cat walked across the keyboard and now the entire network is down. "Sir, did you try restarting?" "Beta, I paid for this internet!"
normalised: Don't even get me started on the users. Bless their hearts, they're the reason we have jobs. But they also believe that turning the computer off and on again will solve literally any problem. And they will call you at three A-M because their cat walked across the keyboard and now the entire network is down. "Sir, did you try restarting?" "Beta, I paid for this internet!"

unnormalised: Then there are the "urgent" requests. Everything is "urgent." Every email is flagged "high priority." Every problem is a "critical system failure." Even when it's just Mrs. Sharma can’t find the Bollywood dance playlist she saved on her desktop. Priorities, people, priorities!
normalised: Then there are the "urgent" requests. Everything is "urgent." Every email is flagged "high priority." Every problem is a "critical system failure." Even when it's just Mrs. Sharma can’t find the Bollywood dance playlist she saved on her desktop. Priorities, people, priorities!

unnormalised: Let's not forget the joys of patching systems at 2 AM on a Saturday. Because nothing says "weekend" like staring at lines of code while your friends are out partying. Just remember to have plenty of chai and samosas on hand. They're the fuel that keeps Indian IT running.
normalised: Let's not forget the joys of patching systems at two A-M on a Saturday. Because nothing says "weekend" like staring at lines of code while your friends are out partying. Just remember to have plenty of chai and samosas on hand. They're the fuel that keeps Indian I-T running.

unnormalised: And the internet speeds? Well, let's just say that "lightning fast" is a relative term. You'll develop a Zen-like patience waiting for files to download. Think of it as a test of your spiritual endurance. Consider it a life lesson in delayed gratification.
normalised: And the internet speeds? Well, let's just say that "lightning fast" is a relative term. You'll develop a Zen-like patience waiting for files to download. Think of it as a test of your spiritual endurance. Consider it a life lesson in delayed gratification.

unnormalised: But hey, it's not all bad. You get to wear comfortable clothes (at least until that client meeting), you're constantly learning new things, and you get the satisfaction of knowing you're keeping the digital world running. Plus, the salaries are pretty good, especially when you factor in the exchange rate if you decide to *prepone* your career abroad! Maybe you'll even be able to afford that new Royal Enfield you've been eyeing.
normalised: But hey, it's not all bad. You get to wear comfortable clothes (at least until that client meeting), you're constantly learning new things, and you get the satisfaction of knowing you're keeping the digital world running. Plus, the salaries are pretty good, especially when you factor in the exchange rate if you decide to prepone your career abroad! Maybe you'll even be able to afford that new Royal Enfield you've been eyeing.

unnormalised: So, if you're still brave enough to venture into the world of IT, welcome to the club! Just remember to keep your sense of humour, your caffeine levels high, and your backup drive ready. And always, always, always back up your data. Your sanity depends on it. Good luck, and may your code compile error-free! Maybe the IT gods will favor you and you won't have to deal with that Win XP machine after all! Remember, Ctrl+Alt+Delete is your best friend. Unless it's not. Then you're on your own.
normalised: So, if you're still brave enough to venture into the world of I-T, welcome to the club! Just remember to keep your sense of humor, your caffeine levels high, and your backup drive ready. And always, always, always back up your data. Your sanity depends on it. Good luck, and may your code compile error-free! Maybe the I-T gods will favor you and you won't have to deal with that Win X-P machine after all! Remember, Control plus Alt plus Delete is your best friend. Unless it's not. Then you're on your own.
